text.p: Turkey's Islamist Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan slammed his opponents on Tuesday as secular "fascists" and presented himself as the guardian of democracy.

"The fascist secularists are confined to history now. Fascist secularism is being replaced by civilised secularism and Western secularism in Turkey," Erbakan told a meeting of his Welfare Party in Ankara.

The military-dominated National Security Council (MGK) issued a warning to Erbakan at the end of February, ordering him to clamp down on Islamist activity that the generals say is a threat to the country's official secular constitution.
The military objected to measures planned by Erbakan's government to relax laws on Islamic headgear in public work-places and build mosques in traditionally secular strongholds.
But Erbakan, who only reluctantly signed the MGK declaration, said the military's demands infringe religious freedom and human rights.
"To pose secularism against religion is ignorance," he said.

The cabinet is now due to discuss the military's demands, inlcuding enforcing the bans on Islamist dress, at a weekly meeting on Thursday. Coalition partner Tansu Ciller has proposed a parliamentary debate into the measures.

In a series of meetings last week Erbakan failed to get the backing of other political party leaders -- even that of Ciller's conservative party -- in his bid to forge a front against the MGK's pressure in the name of democratic freedom.
"The artificial agenda of the last few days, the secular-anti-secular debate and the meetings we had with the poitical leaders showed who was on the side of democracy," Erbakan said.
Erbakan became modern Turkey's first Islamist leader last June in a coalition agreement with pro-Western Foreign Minister Ciller's DYP.
